breeds.title: Dog Breeds Encyclopedia
breeds.subtitle: Explore detailed information about 25 popular dog breeds, their unique characteristics, and care requirements
breeds.noResults: No breeds found matching your filters.
breeds.breed_golden-retriever_description: Golden Retrievers are friendly, intelligent, and devoted dogs that make wonderful family companions. They are known for their beautiful golden coat and gentle temperament.
breeds.breed_golden-retriever_careNote_0: Requires daily exercise and mental stimulation
breeds.breed_golden-retriever_careNote_1: Needs regular brushing 2-3 times per week
breeds.breed_golden-retriever_careNote_2: Prone to hip dysplasia and certain cancers
breeds.breed_golden-retriever_careNote_4: Excellent swimmers and love water activities
breeds.breed_labrador-retriever_description: Labs are America's most popular breed, known for their friendly nature, intelligence, and versatility. They excel as family pets, service dogs, and hunting companions.
breeds.breed_labrador-retriever_careNote_0: Need plenty of exercise to prevent obesity
breeds.breed_labrador-retriever_careNote_3: May be prone to hip and elbow dysplasia
breeds.breed_labrador-retriever_careNote_4: Love to retrieve and play fetch
breeds.breed_german-shepherd_description: German Shepherds are highly intelligent, versatile working dogs known for their courage, loyalty, and trainability. They excel in police work, search and rescue, and as family guardians.
breeds.breed_german-shepherd_careNote_0: Requires extensive daily exercise and mental challenges
breeds.breed_german-shepherd_careNote_1: Needs early socialization and consistent training
breeds.breed_german-shepherd_careNote_2: Double coat sheds heavily twice a year
breeds.breed_german-shepherd_careNote_4: Natural protectors, may be wary of strangers
breeds.breed_french-bulldog_description: French Bulldogs are compact, muscular dogs with distinctive bat ears. They are affectionate, adaptable companions perfect for apartment living.
breeds.breed_french-bulldog_careNote_1: Cannot swim well due to body structure
breeds.breed_french-bulldog_careNote_2: Minimal exercise needs, short walks sufficient
breeds.breed_beagle_description: Beagles are small scent hounds with incredible noses and merry personalities. They make excellent family pets and are known for their distinctive howl.
breeds.breed_beagle_careNote_0: Follow their nose - secure fencing essential
breeds.breed_beagle_careNote_1: Can be vocal, may howl or bay
breeds.breed_beagle_careNote_2: Food-motivated but can be stubborn in training
breeds.breed_beagle_careNote_3: Need regular exercise to prevent obesity
breeds.breed_beagle_careNote_4: Love companionship, don't do well alone
breeds.breed_poodle_description: Poodles are highly intelligent, athletic dogs with hypoallergenic coats. They come in three sizes and excel in obedience and agility.
breeds.breed_poodle_careNote_2: Highly trainable, excels in dog sports
breeds.breed_poodle_careNote_3: Needs mental stimulation to prevent boredom
breeds.breed_bulldog_description: Bulldogs are gentle, dignified dogs with a distinctive wrinkled face and pushed-in nose. Despite their tough appearance, they are sweet and dependable companions.
breeds.breed_bulldog_careNote_0: Cannot tolerate heat - keep cool and hydrated
breeds.breed_bulldog_careNote_2: Short walks only, not athletic dogs
breeds.breed_bulldog_careNote_4: Prone to breathing and joint issues
breeds.breed_rottweiler_description: Rottweilers are powerful, loyal guardians with a calm confidence. With proper training and socialization, they are devoted family companions.
breeds.breed_rottweiler_careNote_0: Requires early socialization and firm training
breeds.breed_rottweiler_careNote_2: Need consistent exercise and mental challenges
breeds.breed_rottweiler_careNote_3: Can be aggressive toward other dogs if not socialized
breeds.breed_rottweiler_careNote_4: Prone to hip dysplasia and obesity
breeds.breed_yorkshire-terrier_description: Yorkshire Terriers are tiny dogs with big personalities. Their long, silky coats and feisty nature make them popular companions.
breeds.breed_yorkshire-terrier_careNote_0: Long coat requires daily brushing and regular grooming
breeds.breed_yorkshire-terrier_careNote_1: Too small for rough play with young children
breeds.breed_yorkshire-terrier_careNote_4: Confident and bold despite small size
breeds.breed_boxer_description: Boxers are energetic, playful dogs known for their patience with children and protective nature. They have a distinctive square jaw and muscular build.
breeds.breed_boxer_careNote_0: Remain puppy-like and playful well into adulthood
breeds.breed_boxer_careNote_2: Can be exuberant jumpers - training needed
breeds.breed_border-collie_description: Border Collies are widely regarded as the most intelligent dog breed. Originally bred for herding sheep, they are incredibly energetic, athletic, and excel in dog sports and working roles.
breeds.breed_border-collie_careNote_0: Require extensive mental and physical stimulation daily
breeds.breed_border-collie_careNote_1: Excel in agility, flyball, and herding trials
breeds.breed_border-collie_careNote_2: May try to herd children and other pets
breeds.breed_border-collie_careNote_3: Need a job or purpose to prevent destructive behavior
breeds.breed_australian-shepherd_description: Despite the name, Australian Shepherds were developed in California. These versatile herding dogs are known for their striking coats, intelligence, and boundless energy.
breeds.breed_australian-shepherd_careNote_0: Need several hours of exercise and mental stimulation daily
breeds.breed_australian-shepherd_careNote_1: May have blue eyes or heterochromia
breeds.breed_australian-shepherd_careNote_2: Strong herding instinct - may nip at heels
breeds.breed_australian-shepherd_careNote_4: Best suited for active families or working roles
breeds.breed_siberian-husky_description: Siberian Huskies are striking dogs bred by the Chukchi people of Siberia for sled pulling. They are known for their blue eyes, thick coats, and incredible endurance.
breeds.breed_siberian-husky_careNote_0: Extremely heavy shedding, especially during seasonal blows
breeds.breed_siberian-husky_careNote_1: Known escape artists - need secure fencing
breeds.breed_siberian-husky_careNote_2: High prey drive towards small animals
breeds.breed_siberian-husky_careNote_3: Very vocal - known for howling and "talking"
breeds.breed_siberian-husky_careNote_4: Cannot tolerate heat well due to thick double coat
breeds.breed_dachshund_description: Dachshunds, also known as "wiener dogs," were bred to hunt badgers. Their long bodies and short legs make them instantly recognizable. They come in smooth, wirehaired, and longhaired varieties.
breeds.breed_dachshund_careNote_0: Prone to back problems - avoid jumping and stairs
breeds.breed_dachshund_careNote_1: Can be stubborn and difficult to housetrain
breeds.breed_dachshund_careNote_2: Strong prey drive and tendency to dig
breeds.breed_dachshund_careNote_3: May be snappy with young children
breeds.breed_dachshund_careNote_4: Require weight management to prevent back strain
breeds.breed_great-dane_description: Great Danes are gentle giants known for their massive size and calm demeanor. Despite their imposing stature, they are affectionate and make excellent family companions.
breeds.breed_great-dane_careNote_0: Require careful nutrition during growth phase
breeds.breed_great-dane_careNote_1: Prone to bloat - feed smaller meals multiple times daily
breeds.breed_great-dane_careNote_2: Need large living space despite calm nature
breeds.breed_great-dane_careNote_4: Early training essential due to massive size
breeds.breed_pembroke-welsh-corgi_description: Pembroke Welsh Corgis are small herding dogs with big personalities. Famous as the preferred breed of Queen Elizabeth II, these intelligent dogs are active, loyal, and trainable.
breeds.breed_pembroke-welsh-corgi_careNote_1: Prone to obesity - monitor food intake
breeds.breed_pembroke-welsh-corgi_careNote_2: May nip at heels due to herding instinct
breeds.breed_pembroke-welsh-corgi_careNote_3: Back problems due to long body - limit jumping
breeds.breed_pembroke-welsh-corgi_careNote_4: Very vocal and alert - excellent watchdogs
breeds.breed_shih-tzu_description: Shih Tzus were bred as companion dogs for Chinese royalty. These small, sturdy dogs have flowing coats and friendly personalities, making them ideal lap dogs and companions.
breeds.breed_shih-tzu_careNote_0: Require daily brushing and regular professional grooming
breeds.breed_shih-tzu_careNote_2: Facial hair needs daily cleaning around eyes
breeds.breed_boston-terrier_description: Boston Terriers, nicknamed "American Gentleman," are compact, well-mannered dogs with tuxedo-like markings. They are intelligent, trainable, and make excellent city dogs.
breeds.breed_boston-terrier_careNote_4: Excellent with children and other pets
breeds.breed_pomeranian_description: Pomeranians are tiny dogs with big personalities and fluffy double coats. Despite their small size, they are confident, alert, and make surprisingly good watchdogs.
breeds.breed_pomeranian_careNote_0: Require daily brushing to prevent matting
breeds.breed_pomeranian_careNote_3: Fragile - not suitable for homes with young children
breeds.breed_pomeranian_careNote_4: May develop "small dog syndrome" without proper training
breeds.breed_cavalier-king-charles-spaniel_desc: Cavalier King Charles Spaniels are gentle, affectionate toy spaniels known for their expressive eyes and silky coats. They adapt well to various lifestyles and are excellent therapy dogs.
breeds.breed_cavalier-king-charles-spaniel_care: Prone to heart conditions - regular vet checkups essential
Should not be left alone for long periods
Adapt well to apartment or house living
breeds.breed_doberman-pinscher_description: Doberman Pinschers are powerful, athletic dogs bred as guard dogs. With proper training and socialization, they are loyal family companions and excellent protection dogs.
breeds.breed_doberman-pinscher_careNote_0: Require firm, consistent training from early age
breeds.breed_doberman-pinscher_careNote_1: Need extensive daily exercise and mental stimulation
breeds.breed_doberman-pinscher_careNote_3: Can be aggressive toward other dogs if not socialized
breeds.breed_doberman-pinscher_careNote_4: Prone to bloat and heart conditions
breeds.breed_bernese-mountain-dog_description: Bernese Mountain Dogs are large, gentle giants with striking tri-colored coats. Originally bred as farm dogs in the Swiss Alps, they are calm, loyal, and excellent with families.
breeds.breed_bernese-mountain-dog_careNote_2: Prone to cancer and hip dysplasia
breeds.breed_bernese-mountain-dog_careNote_4: Need moderate exercise but not excessive
breeds.breed_cocker-spaniel_description: Cocker Spaniels are merry, gentle sporting dogs with beautiful flowing coats. They were originally bred as hunting dogs but now are popular family companions known for their sweet nature.
breeds.breed_cocker-spaniel_careNote_1: Ears prone to infections - need frequent cleaning
breeds.breed_cocker-spaniel_careNote_2: Can be prone to separation anxiety
breeds.breed_cocker-spaniel_careNote_4: Very trainable and eager to please
breeds.breed_akita_description: Akitas are large, powerful Japanese dogs bred for guarding royalty and hunting large game. They are dignified, loyal, and devoted to their families but can be aloof with strangers.
breeds.breed_akita_careNote_0: Can be aggressive toward other dogs, especially same sex
breeds.breed_akita_careNote_1: Require experienced owner and consistent training
breeds.breed_akita_careNote_2: Strong prey drive - not safe with small pets
breeds.breed_akita_careNote_3: Very loyal but can be overprotective
breeds.breed_chihuahua_description: Chihuahuas are the smallest dog breed, weighing no more than 6 pounds. Despite their tiny size, they have huge personalities and are fiercely loyal to their owners.
breeds.breed_chihuahua_careNote_0: Very fragile - not suitable for homes with young children
breeds.breed_chihuahua_careNote_2: Can be yappy and suspicious of strangers
breeds.breed_chihuahua_careNote_3: Sensitive to cold - may need sweaters
breeds.breed_chihuahua_careNote_4: Tend to bond strongly with one person

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.subtitle: Common questions from dog owners answered by experts
faq.noResults: No questions found matching your search.
faq.cantFindAnswer: Can't find the answer you're looking for? Our dog care experts are here to help!
faq.faq_how-much-sleep_q: How much sleep does my dog need?
faq.faq_how-much-sleep_a: Dogs typically need 12-14 hours of sleep per day, though this varies by age and breed. Puppies and senior dogs may sleep up to 18-20 hours daily. Large breeds tend to sleep more than small breeds. If your dog seems to sleep excessively or has trouble sleeping, consult your vet as it could indicate a health issue.
faq.faq_first-vet-visit_q: When should I take my new puppy to the vet?
faq.faq_first-vet-visit_a: Schedule a vet visit within the first week of bringing your puppy home, ideally within 48-72 hours. The vet will perform a health check, discuss vaccination schedules, deworming, microchipping, spay/neuter timing, and answer any questions. Bring any medical records from the breeder or shelter.
faq.faq_potty-training-time_q: How long does potty training take?
faq.faq_potty-training-time_a: Most puppies can be reliably potty trained by 4-6 months old, but some may take up to a year. Success depends on consistency, your schedule, the puppy's age, and previous training. Take puppies out every 1-2 hours, immediately after eating, drinking, playing, or waking up. Praise successes immediately and never punish accidents.
faq.faq_can-eat-human-food_a: Some human foods are safe in moderation (plain chicken, carrots, apples, peanut butter without xylitol), but many are toxic. NEVER feed: chocolate, grapes, raisins, onions, garlic, macadamia nuts, xylitol, alcohol, avocado, or cooked bones. Human food should not exceed 10% of daily calories. Always research before sharing food with your dog.
faq.faq_why-eat-grass_q: Why does my dog eat grass?
faq.faq_why-eat-grass_a: Grass eating is common and usually harmless. Reasons include: upset stomach (grass may induce vomiting), dietary needs (seeking fiber), boredom, or simply liking the taste. Most dogs who eat grass don't vomit. However, if it's excessive, accompanied by vomiting, or if the grass is chemically treated, consult your vet. Ensure your dog has a complete diet and plenty of enrichment.
faq.faq_stop-barking_q: How do I stop excessive barking?
faq.faq_stop-barking_a: First, identify why your dog barks (alerting, attention-seeking, anxiety, boredom, fear). Then address the cause: increase exercise and mental stimulation, desensitize to triggers, teach "quiet" command, ignore attention-seeking barking, and reward quiet behavior. Never yell (they think you're barking too). For persistent issues, consult a professional trainer. Some breeds are naturally more vocal.
faq.faq_socialize-adult-dog_q: Can I socialize an adult dog?
faq.faq_socialize-adult-dog_a: Yes, though it's easier with puppies during the critical 3-14 week period. Adult dog socialization requires patience and gradual exposure. Start with calm, controlled environments and positive associations. Never force interactions. Consider working with a professional trainer, especially for fearful or reactive dogs. Progress slowly and celebrate small victories. Some dogs may always have limitations based on their history.
faq.faq_how-often-bathe_q: How often should I bathe my dog?
faq.faq_how-often-bathe_a: Most dogs need bathing every 4-6 weeks, but this varies widely. Factors include coat type, lifestyle, skin conditions, and odor. Overbathing strips natural oils and can cause dry, itchy skin. Dogs with skin conditions may need medicated baths weekly. Short-haired, indoor dogs may only need bathing every 2-3 months. Always use dog-specific shampoo.
faq.faq_safe-leave-alone_q: How long can I safely leave my dog alone?
faq.faq_safe-leave-alone_a: Adult dogs can typically be left alone for 4-6 hours. Puppies under 6 months should not be alone longer than their age in months plus one (3-month-old = 4 hours max). Consider these factors: potty needs, exercise requirements, anxiety levels, and age. Provide water, safe toys, and comfortable space. For longer periods, arrange for a dog walker or pet sitter.
faq.faq_dog-insurance-worth_a: Pet insurance can be valuable for managing unexpected veterinary costs. It's most beneficial when purchased early (before pre-existing conditions develop). Consider: your financial situation, breed-specific health risks, deductible and coverage options, and whether you have emergency savings. Insurance doesn't cover pre-existing conditions, routine care (unless you pay extra), or certain hereditary conditions depending on the policy. Compare multiple companies.
faq.faq_signs-of-pain_q: How do I know if my dog is in pain?
faq.faq_signs-of-pain_a: Signs of pain include: limping, reluctance to move or jump, decreased appetite, excessive panting or drooling, whining or whimpering, hiding, aggression when touched, changes in posture, restlessness, or excessive licking of one area. Dogs often hide pain, so subtle changes matter. Any sudden behavior change warrants a vet visit. Senior dogs may develop arthritis pain that develops gradually.
faq.faq_puppy-biting_q: How do I stop my puppy from biting?
faq.faq_puppy-biting_a: Puppy biting (mouthing) is normal exploration and teething behavior. To address it: yelp or say "ouch" and stop play when bitten, redirect to appropriate chew toys, never use hands as toys, avoid rough play that encourages biting, provide frozen toys for teething, and reward gentle behavior. Consistency is key. If biting is aggressive rather than playful, consult a trainer. Most puppies outgrow it by 6-7 months.
faq.faq_introduce-new-dog_q: How do I introduce a new dog to my current dog?
faq.faq_introduce-new-dog_a: Introduce dogs on neutral territory (not your home) with both on leash. Walk them parallel at a distance, gradually closer. Watch for relaxed body language. If positive, allow brief greetings, then separate. Repeat over several meetings. At home, supervise closely, feed separately, provide individual resources, and give both attention. Some dogs click immediately, others take weeks. Never force interactions. Consider professional help for reactive dogs.
faq.faq_crate-training-benefits_q: Should I crate train my dog?
faq.faq_crate-training-benefits_a: Crate training is highly recommended. Benefits include: aids house training, provides a safe space, prevents destructive behavior when unsupervised, facilitates travel, and helps with vet visits. Dogs naturally den, so most find crates comforting when properly introduced. Never use as punishment. The crate should be large enough to stand, turn, and lie down. Puppies shouldn't be crated longer than they can hold their bladder.
faq.faq_spay-neuter-when_q: When should I spay or neuter my dog?
faq.faq_spay-neuter-when_a: Traditional timing is 6 months, but recent research suggests waiting may benefit large breeds. Discuss with your vet based on your dog's breed, size, and health. Large/giant breeds may benefit from waiting until 12-18 months for bone growth. Small breeds can be done at 6 months. Benefits include preventing unwanted litters, reducing certain cancers, and decreasing roaming/marking behaviors. There are also risks to consider.
faq.faq_dog-cold_q: Can dogs catch colds from humans?
faq.faq_dog-cold_a: No, dogs cannot catch human colds or flu. However, dogs can get their own respiratory infections (kennel cough, canine influenza) with similar symptoms: coughing, sneezing, nasal discharge, lethargy. If your dog shows these signs, especially after boarding or dog parks, consult your vet. Some respiratory infections are contagious among dogs. Keep sick dogs away from other pets.
faq.faq_why-sniff-everything_q: Why does my dog sniff everything on walks?
faq.faq_why-sniff-everything_a: Sniffing is how dogs explore and understand their world. Their sense of smell is 10,000-100,000 times more acute than ours. Sniffing provides mental stimulation, information about other animals, and is naturally calming. Allow sniff breaks during walks - it's enriching and tiring. Consider "sniffari" walks where sniffing is the primary goal. Forced rapid walks without sniffing can increase anxiety.
faq.faq_dog-dreams_a: Yes, dogs dream. You may notice twitching, paw movements, muffled barks, or rapid eye movement during sleep. Dogs enter REM sleep about 20 minutes after falling asleep. They likely dream about daily activities: playing, eating, interacting with you. Puppies and senior dogs dream more than middle-aged dogs. Never wake a dreaming dog suddenly as they may startle and snap reflexively.
faq.faq_best-first-dog_q: What's the best breed for first-time owners?
faq.faq_best-first-dog_a: Good starter breeds include: Labrador Retriever, Golden Retriever, Cavalier King Charles Spaniel, Pug, and mixed breeds. Look for: trainability, friendly temperament, moderate energy, and size appropriate for your living situation. Consider adopting an adult dog - temperament is already known, and they're often calmer than puppies. Research breeds thoroughly, meet individual dogs, and honestly assess your lifestyle, time, and commitment level.
faq.faq_dog-age-calculator_q: How do I calculate my dog's age in human years?
faq.faq_dog-age-calculator_a: The old "multiply by 7" rule is inaccurate. Dogs age faster in their early years. A more accurate method: the first year equals about 15 human years, second year adds 9 years, then each year after is about 4-5 human years. However, this varies by size - small dogs live longer and age slower than large breeds. A 10-year-old small dog might be equivalent to 56 human years, while a large dog might be 66.

behavior.title: Dog Behavior Guide
behavior.subtitle: Understanding your dog's behaviors, body language, and what they really mean
behavior.behavior_tail-wagging_description: Dogs wag their tails to communicate various emotions and intentions.
behavior.behavior_tail-wagging_meaning: The meaning varies based on speed, position, and context. A broad, mid-level wag usually indicates happiness. A high, stiff wag can signal alertness or aggression. A low wag may indicate insecurity or submission.
behavior.behavior_tail-wagging_whatToDo_0: Observe the entire body language, not just the tail
behavior.behavior_tail-wagging_whatToDo_1: Pay attention to the speed and height of the wag
behavior.behavior_tail-wagging_whatToDo_3: Look for other signs like ear position and facial expression
behavior.behavior_tail-wagging_whenToWorry_0: Tail wagging with stiff body posture
behavior.behavior_tail-wagging_whenToWorry_1: High, rapid wagging with showing teeth
behavior.behavior_tail-wagging_whenToWorry_2: Tail tucked between legs with trembling
behavior.behavior_tail-wagging_whenToWorry_3: Sudden changes in tail position with other stress signs
behavior.behavior_tail-wagging_tip_0: A relaxed, full-body wag is the most positive sign
behavior.behavior_tail-wagging_tip_1: Each dog has individual wagging patterns
behavior.behavior_tail-wagging_tip_2: Puppies learn tail communication from other dogs
behavior.behavior_tail-wagging_tip_3: Tail wagging is not always a sign of friendliness
behavior.behavior_barking_description: Barking is a primary vocal communication method for dogs, used to express various needs and emotions.
behavior.behavior_barking_meaning: Dogs bark for many reasons: alerting, seeking attention, expressing excitement, fear, boredom, or responding to other dogs. The pitch, duration, and frequency convey different messages.
behavior.behavior_barking_whatToDo_0: Identify the trigger or cause of barking
behavior.behavior_barking_whatToDo_1: Don't yell at your dog (they may think you're barking too)
behavior.behavior_barking_whatToDo_3: Provide adequate exercise and mental stimulation
behavior.behavior_barking_whenToWorry_0: Excessive barking that disrupts daily life
behavior.behavior_barking_tip_0: Different bark types have different meanings
behavior.behavior_barking_tip_1: Some breeds are naturally more vocal
behavior.behavior_barking_tip_2: Barking can be a sign of separation anxiety
behavior.behavior_barking_tip_3: Never use bark collars without consulting a trainer
behavior.behavior_digging_description: Digging is a natural instinct for dogs, often related to hunting, comfort, or entertainment.
behavior.behavior_digging_meaning: Dogs dig for various reasons: to create a cool spot to lie down, to bury treasures, out of boredom, to escape, or following scent trails. Some breeds have stronger digging instincts.
behavior.behavior_digging_whatToDo_4: Consider the reason behind the digging
behavior.behavior_digging_whenToWorry_0: Digging to escape the yard repeatedly
behavior.behavior_digging_whenToWorry_1: Compulsive digging causing injury to paws
behavior.behavior_digging_whenToWorry_3: Sudden onset in an older dog
behavior.behavior_digging_tip_0: Terriers and hounds have strong digging instincts
behavior.behavior_digging_tip_1: Hot weather increases digging for cooling
behavior.behavior_jumping_description: Jumping up on people is a common social behavior, especially in puppies and excited dogs.
behavior.behavior_jumping_meaning: Dogs jump to greet, seek attention, show excitement, or establish dominance. It's often a learned behavior that gets reinforced by human reactions.
behavior.behavior_jumping_whatToDo_0: Turn away and ignore jumping behavior
behavior.behavior_jumping_whatToDo_3: Be consistent - don't allow it sometimes
behavior.behavior_jumping_whatToDo_4: Ask visitors to follow the same rules
behavior.behavior_jumping_tip_0: Never knee or push jumping dogs
behavior.behavior_jumping_tip_1: Consistency is key to stopping this behavior
behavior.behavior_licking_description: Licking is a natural dog behavior with various meanings depending on context.
behavior.behavior_licking_meaning: Dogs lick to show affection, seek attention, explore their environment, self-soothe, or because they like the taste. Mother dogs lick puppies for grooming and bonding.
behavior.behavior_licking_whatToDo_2: Check for skin issues if self-licking excessively
behavior.behavior_licking_whatToDo_4: Train an alternative behavior if unwanted
behavior.behavior_licking_whenToWorry_2: Licking accompanied by other stress signs
behavior.behavior_licking_tip_1: Some dogs are naturally "lickier" than others
behavior.behavior_licking_tip_2: Can be a sign of nausea or digestive issues
behavior.behavior_chewing_description: Chewing is a natural and important behavior for dogs of all ages.
behavior.behavior_chewing_meaning: Puppies chew during teething. Adult dogs chew to keep jaws strong, teeth clean, and to relieve stress or boredom. It's also a way to explore the world.
behavior.behavior_chewing_whatToDo_3: Use positive reinforcement for good chewing
behavior.behavior_chewing_tip_0: Puppies need to chew - it's not misbehavior
behavior.behavior_chewing_tip_2: Frozen toys can soothe teething puppies
behavior.behavior_play-bow_description: The play bow is a distinctive posture where the dog lowers their front end while keeping their rear up.
behavior.behavior_play-bow_meaning: This is a clear invitation to play and signals that any following behavior is playful, not aggressive. It's a universal dog communication signal.
behavior.behavior_play-bow_whenToWorry_0: Rarely needs concern - it's a positive behavior
behavior.behavior_play-bow_whenToWorry_1: If accompanied by rigid body language
behavior.behavior_play-bow_tip_0: Dogs use this even with humans
behavior.behavior_play-bow_tip_1: It's a learned social skill from puppyhood
behavior.behavior_play-bow_tip_2: Some dogs add barks or play growls
behavior.behavior_resource-guarding_description: Resource guarding is when a dog protects food, toys, spaces, or people from others.
behavior.behavior_resource-guarding_meaning: This is a natural survival instinct but can become problematic. Dogs may freeze, growl, snap, or bite to protect valued resources.
behavior.behavior_resource-guarding_whatToDo_2: Practice trading games with lower-value items
behavior.behavior_resource-guarding_whatToDo_3: Feed in a quiet, stress-free area
behavior.behavior_resource-guarding_tip_1: Never approach a guarding dog directly
behavior.behavior_resource-guarding_tip_2: Some breeds are more prone to guarding
behavior.behavior_zoomies_description: Frenetic Random Activity Periods (FRAPs), commonly called "zoomies," are sudden bursts of energy.
behavior.behavior_zoomies_meaning: Zoomies are a natural way for dogs to release pent-up energy or express excitement. Common after baths, in the evening, or when very happy.
behavior.behavior_zoomies_whatToDo_2: Don't chase or get in the way
behavior.behavior_zoomies_whenToWorry_0: Rarely a concern - it's normal behavior
behavior.behavior_zoomies_tip_0: More common in puppies and young dogs
behavior.behavior_zoomies_tip_3: Sign of a happy, healthy dog
behavior.behavior_circling-before-lying_descripti: Many dogs circle one or more times before settling down to rest.
behavior.behavior_circling-before-lying_meaning: This is an inherited behavior from wild ancestors who circled to flatten grass, check for threats, and create a comfortable sleeping spot. It can also help regulate body temperature.
behavior.behavior_circling-before-lying_whenToWor: Could indicate pain or neurological issues
behavior.behavior_circling-before-lying_tip_1: Some dogs do it every time, some never
behavior.behavior_circling-before-lying_tip_2: May be more pronounced in certain breeds
behavior.behavior_head-tilting_description: Dogs often tilt their heads when listening or trying to understand something.
behavior.behavior_head-tilting_meaning: Head tilting may help dogs locate sound sources, see past their muzzles, or process new information. It's also a response that gets positive human reactions.
behavior.behavior_head-tilting_whatToDo_0: Talk to your dog - they're listening
behavior.behavior_head-tilting_whatToDo_2: Use it as a sign they're engaged
behavior.behavior_head-tilting_whenToWorry_0: Persistent head tilt to one side
behavior.behavior_head-tilting_whenToWorry_1: Head tilt with loss of balance
behavior.behavior_head-tilting_whenToWorry_2: Accompanied by ear scratching or discharge
behavior.behavior_head-tilting_whenToWorry_3: Could indicate ear infection or vestibular issues
behavior.behavior_head-tilting_tip_0: Often happens with new words or sounds
behavior.behavior_head-tilting_tip_1: Some dogs do it more than others
behavior.behavior_head-tilting_tip_2: May be trying to read your expressions
behavior.behavior_head-tilting_tip_3: Can be trained as a cute trick
behavior.behavior_yawning_description: Dogs yawn in various contexts, not always because they're tired.
behavior.behavior_yawning_meaning: Yawning can indicate tiredness, but also stress, anticipation, or as a calming signal to diffuse tension. Dogs may yawn when confused or trying to self-soothe.
behavior.behavior_yawning_whatToDo_0: Assess the context of the yawn
behavior.behavior_yawning_whatToDo_2: Reduce stress if yawning seems anxiety-related
behavior.behavior_yawning_whatToDo_3: Allow rest if they seem tired
behavior.behavior_yawning_tip_1: Can be contagious from humans to dogs
behavior.behavior_yawning_tip_3: Normal before sleep or after waking
behavior.behavior_growling_description: Growling is an important warning signal that should never be punished.
behavior.behavior_growling_meaning: Growling is a dog's way of saying "I'm uncomfortable" or "back off." It can indicate fear, possessiveness, pain, or a warning before aggression. It's an important communication that prevents escalation to biting.
behavior.behavior_growling_whatToDo_0: Never punish growling - it's valuable communication
behavior.behavior_growling_whatToDo_3: Address the underlying cause (fear, pain, resource guarding)
behavior.behavior_growling_whatToDo_4: Work with a professional trainer for aggression issues
behavior.behavior_growling_whatToDo_5: Teach children to respect a growling dog
behavior.behavior_growling_whenToWorry_0: Frequent growling with no apparent trigger
behavior.behavior_growling_whenToWorry_1: Growling that escalates to snapping or biting
behavior.behavior_growling_whenToWorry_2: Growling accompanied by stiff body language
behavior.behavior_growling_tip_0: Growling is the last warning before a bite
behavior.behavior_growling_tip_1: Punishing growling makes dogs bite without warning
behavior.behavior_growling_tip_2: Play growling is different from aggressive growling
behavior.behavior_growling_tip_3: Watch the whole body, not just the vocalization
behavior.behavior_whining_description: Whining is a vocal communication expressing needs, excitement, or distress.
behavior.behavior_whining_meaning: Dogs whine to request attention, food, or to go outside. It can also indicate anxiety, pain, or excitement. Puppies whine more than adults and may whine from separation anxiety.
behavior.behavior_whining_whenToWorry_0: Excessive whining with no clear cause
behavior.behavior_whining_whenToWorry_1: Whining with signs of pain (limping, hunching)
behavior.behavior_whining_tip_2: Senior dogs may whine due to cognitive decline
behavior.behavior_whining_tip_3: Can indicate medical issues - rule those out first
behavior.behavior_pawing_description: Dogs use their paws to communicate and get attention.
behavior.behavior_pawing_meaning: Pawing is usually an attention-seeking behavior or a request for petting. Puppies paw at their mothers for food. It can also indicate anxiety or a learned behavior that gets results.
behavior.behavior_pawing_whatToDo_0: Decide if you want to encourage this behavior
behavior.behavior_pawing_whatToDo_1: Ignore pawing if you don't want it reinforced
behavior.behavior_pawing_whatToDo_4: Check if there's a specific need (food, outside)
behavior.behavior_pawing_whenToWorry_0: Excessive pawing at face or eyes
behavior.behavior_pawing_whenToWorry_1: Pawing accompanied by whining or distress
behavior.behavior_pawing_tip_0: Giving attention when pawing reinforces it
behavior.behavior_pawing_tip_1: Some dogs paw when excited or happy
behavior.behavior_pawing_tip_2: Can be taught as a "shake" or "high five" trick
behavior.behavior_pawing_tip_3: Teach "four on the floor" for calmer interactions
behavior.behavior_mounting_description: Mounting is normal dog behavior with various non-sexual meanings.
behavior.behavior_mounting_meaning: Despite common belief, mounting is usually not sexual. It can indicate play, over-excitement, stress, dominance display, or simply a learned behavior. Common in both intact and neutered dogs.
behavior.behavior_mounting_whatToDo_1: Remove dog from situation if over-stimulated
behavior.behavior_mounting_whenToWorry_1: Mounting that leads to fights with other dogs
behavior.behavior_mounting_whenToWorry_3: Inability to redirect or stop behavior
behavior.behavior_mounting_tip_0: More common in puppies and young dogs
behavior.behavior_mounting_tip_1: Neutering may reduce but won't eliminate behavior
behavior.behavior_mounting_tip_3: Some dogs mount when they don't know what else to do
behavior.behavior_sniffing_description: Sniffing is how dogs explore and understand their world.
behavior.behavior_sniffing_meaning: Dogs have an incredible sense of smell and gather information through scent. Sniffing other dogs, people, and objects is normal. Allowing sniffing on walks is mentally stimulating and important for dogs.
behavior.behavior_sniffing_whatToDo_0: Allow reasonable sniffing time on walks
behavior.behavior_sniffing_whatToDo_1: Use "let's go" command when it's time to move on
behavior.behavior_sniffing_whatToDo_3: Try scent work or nose games
behavior.behavior_sniffing_whatToDo_4: Don't constantly pull dog away from sniffing
behavior.behavior_sniffing_whenToWorry_1: Sniffing accompanied by licking or eating objects
behavior.behavior_sniffing_whenToWorry_2: Inability to focus on anything else
behavior.behavior_sniffing_whenToWorry_3: May indicate anxiety or compulsive disorder
behavior.behavior_sniffing_tip_0: Sniffing is mental exercise - very tiring
behavior.behavior_sniffing_tip_3: Some breeds are bred to use their nose more
behavior.behavior_panting_description: Panting serves multiple functions and isn't always about temperature.
behavior.behavior_panting_meaning: Dogs pant to cool down (they don't sweat like humans). However, panting can also indicate stress, anxiety, excitement, pain, or illness. Context is important.
behavior.behavior_panting_whatToDo_2: Assess for stress or anxiety triggers
behavior.behavior_panting_whatToDo_3: Watch for other symptoms if excessive
behavior.behavior_panting_whenToWorry_1: Panting with blue or pale gums
behavior.behavior_panting_whenToWorry_3: Panting with distress, whining, or pacing
behavior.behavior_panting_whenToWorry_4: Could indicate heatstroke, pain, or heart/lung issues
behavior.behavior_panting_tip_1: Stress panting is faster and shallower
behavior.behavior_panting_tip_2: Normal after exercise or in heat
behavior.behavior_panting_tip_3: Nighttime panting may indicate pain or cognitive issues
behavior.behavior_scratching-door_description: Door scratching can indicate a need to go out or separation anxiety.
behavior.behavior_scratching-door_meaning: Dogs scratch doors to communicate needs (bathroom, join you, go outside) or from anxiety when separated. It can become a destructive habit if reinforced.
behavior.behavior_scratching-door_whatToDo_0: Install a bell for dogs to ring instead
behavior.behavior_scratching-door_whenToWorry_3: Scratching accompanied by howling or destruction
behavior.behavior_scratching-door_tip_1: Take dogs out on schedule to prevent scratching
behavior.behavior_scratching-door_tip_3: Protect doors with scratch guards if needed
behavior.behavior_leaning_description: Dogs lean against their owners for various affectionate or anxious reasons.
behavior.behavior_leaning_meaning: Most often, leaning is a sign of affection and wanting to be close. Some dogs lean for security when anxious. Large breeds tend to lean more. It's usually a positive bonding behavior.
behavior.behavior_leaning_whatToDo_1: Gently redirect if you need space
behavior.behavior_leaning_whatToDo_4: Don't reinforce if you want to discourage it
behavior.behavior_leaning_whenToWorry_1: If accompanied by trembling or fear
behavior.behavior_leaning_whenToWorry_2: If dog seems unable to stand independently
behavior.behavior_leaning_whenToWorry_3: Could rarely indicate balance or weakness issues
behavior.behavior_leaning_tip_2: Some dogs lean instead of sitting
behavior.behavior_leaning_tip_3: Can be calming for anxious dogs
behavior.behavior_spinning_description: Spinning behavior can be normal excitement or a compulsive disorder.
behavior.behavior_spinning_meaning: Brief spinning when excited (mealtime, walk time) is normal. Excessive spinning can indicate anxiety, neurological issues, or compulsive disorder. Herding breeds are more prone.
behavior.behavior_spinning_whatToDo_3: For excessive spinning, consult vet and behaviorist
behavior.behavior_spinning_whenToWorry_4: May indicate neurological or behavioral disorder
behavior.behavior_spinning_tip_0: Brief spinning before settling is normal
behavior.behavior_spinning_tip_1: Herding breeds more prone to spinning
behavior.behavior_eating-grass_description: Grass eating is common and usually harmless behavior.
behavior.behavior_eating-grass_meaning: Dogs eat grass for various reasons: to induce vomiting when nauseous, for fiber, out of boredom, or simply because they like the taste. Most experts consider it normal behavior.
behavior.behavior_eating-grass_whatToDo_0: Allow occasional grass eating if safe
behavior.behavior_eating-grass_whatToDo_1: Ensure grass isn't treated with chemicals
behavior.behavior_eating-grass_whatToDo_2: Offer high-fiber diet if eating lots of grass
behavior.behavior_eating-grass_whatToDo_4: Monitor for excessive eating or vomiting
behavior.behavior_eating-grass_whenToWorry_2: Eating grass with loss of appetite
behavior.behavior_eating-grass_whenToWorry_3: May indicate digestive issues or nausea
behavior.behavior_eating-grass_whenToWorry_4: Could be ingesting pesticides or toxins
behavior.behavior_rolling-in-smells_description: Dogs love to roll in foul-smelling substances - a confusing behavior for owners.
behavior.behavior_rolling-in-smells_meaning: This instinctive behavior likely stems from wolves masking their scent for hunting or communicating with their pack about interesting finds. Dogs are attracted to especially pungent smells.
behavior.behavior_rolling-in-smells_whatToDo_0: Supervise in areas with known smelly items
behavior.behavior_rolling-in-smells_whatToDo_2: Keep dogs on leash in areas with dead animals
behavior.behavior_rolling-in-smells_whatToDo_4: Accept it as normal dog behavior
behavior.behavior_rolling-in-smells_whenToWorry_0: Usually not a concern - just unpleasant
behavior.behavior_rolling-in-smells_whenToWorry_1: Watch for skin irritation from substances
behavior.behavior_rolling-in-smells_whenToWorry_2: Ensure they're not rolling in toxins
behavior.behavior_rolling-in-smells_tip_0: All dogs do this - it's instinctive
behavior.behavior_rolling-in-smells_tip_1: They prefer the smellier, the better
behavior.behavior_rolling-in-smells_tip_3: Keep enzymatic cleaner and shampoo handy
behavior.behavior_coprophagia_description: Eating feces is a disturbing but relatively common behavior.
behavior.behavior_coprophagia_meaning: Dogs may eat feces due to nutritional deficiencies, enzyme deficiencies, boredom, stress, learned behavior from mother, or simply because it's available. More common in puppies.
behavior.behavior_coprophagia_whatToDo_2: Rule out medical issues with vet
behavior.behavior_coprophagia_whatToDo_6: Keep litter boxes out of reach
behavior.behavior_coprophagia_whenToWorry_1: If accompanied by weight loss or poor coat
behavior.behavior_coprophagia_tip_2: Cat feces particularly attractive to dogs

care.title: Dog Care Guide
care.subtitle: Essential tips for grooming, exercise, training, health, and safety for your dog
care.care_brushing-basics_description: Brushing your dog's coat is essential for maintaining healthy skin and fur, reducing shedding, and bonding with your pet.
care.care_brushing-basics_frequency: Varies by coat type: short coats weekly, long coats daily
care.care_brushing-basics_tip_0: Brush in the direction of hair growth
care.care_brushing-basics_tip_2: Check for lumps, bumps, or skin issues while brushing
care.care_brushing-basics_tip_3: Make it a positive experience with treats and praise
care.care_brushing-basics_tip_4: Start slowly with puppies to build tolerance
care.care_brushing-basics_tip_5: Use the right brush type for your dog's coat
care.care_brushing-basics_tip_6: Pay extra attention to areas prone to matting
care.care_brushing-basics_warning_0: Never brush over mats - work them out gently or cut carefully
care.care_brushing-basics_warning_1: Watch for skin irritation from over-brushing
care.care_brushing-basics_warning_2: Some dogs are sensitive on their paws and tail
care.care_nail-trimming_description: Proper nail maintenance prevents discomfort, injury, and long-term joint problems.
care.care_nail-trimming_frequency: Every 3-4 weeks, or when you hear clicking on floors
care.care_nail-trimming_tip_0: Trim small amounts frequently rather than large amounts rarely
care.care_nail-trimming_tip_1: Avoid the quick (pink area visible in light nails)
care.care_nail-trimming_tip_2: Have styptic powder ready in case of bleeding
care.care_nail-trimming_tip_3: Desensitize your dog to paw handling from puppyhood
care.care_nail-trimming_tip_4: Consider a grinder for smoother results
care.care_nail-trimming_tip_5: Trim hair between paw pads at the same time
care.care_nail-trimming_warning_0: Cutting the quick is painful and bleeds
care.care_nail-trimming_warning_1: Dark nails make the quick harder to see
care.care_nail-trimming_warning_2: Seek professional help if your dog is fearful or aggressive
care.care_dental-care_description: Dental care is crucial for preventing periodontal disease, which affects 80% of dogs by age 3.
care.care_dental-care_frequency: Daily brushing ideal, minimum 3 times weekly
care.care_dental-care_tip_0: Start dental care early to build acceptance
care.care_dental-care_tip_2: Lift lips gently and brush in circular motions
care.care_dental-care_tip_4: Provide dental chews as supplements, not replacements
care.care_dental-care_tip_6: Check for bad breath, red gums, or loose teeth
care.care_dental-care_warning_0: Human toothpaste is toxic to dogs
care.care_dental-care_warning_1: Dental disease can lead to heart and kidney problems
care.care_daily-exercise_description: Regular exercise is vital for physical health, mental stimulation, and preventing behavioral problems.
care.care_daily-exercise_frequency: Daily, duration varies by breed and age
care.care_daily-exercise_tip_0: Provide 30-120 minutes of exercise daily depending on breed
care.care_daily-exercise_tip_1: Include both physical and mental activities
care.care_daily-exercise_tip_2: Vary exercise types: walks, runs, fetch, swimming
care.care_daily-exercise_tip_3: Exercise before leaving dog alone to reduce anxiety
care.care_daily-exercise_tip_4: Adjust intensity for age and health conditions
care.care_daily-exercise_tip_5: Watch for signs of overexertion in hot weather
care.care_daily-exercise_tip_6: Senior dogs need gentler, shorter sessions
care.care_daily-exercise_tip_7: Puppies need frequent, brief play sessions
care.care_daily-exercise_warning_0: Avoid exercise immediately after meals (bloat risk)
care.care_daily-exercise_warning_2: Growing puppies shouldn't do intensive exercise
care.care_daily-exercise_warning_3: Watch for limping or reluctance to move
care.care_mental-stimulation_description: Mental exercise is as important as physical exercise for a well-balanced dog.
care.care_mental-stimulation_tip_3: Practice scent work and nose games
care.care_mental-stimulation_warning_2: Don't make puzzles too difficult (causes frustration)
care.care_socialization_description: Socialization helps dogs become confident, well-adjusted adults comfortable in various situations.
care.care_socialization_frequency: Critical period: 3-14 weeks, continue throughout life
care.care_socialization_tip_0: Expose puppies to various people, dogs, and environments
care.care_socialization_tip_4: Introduce to different surfaces, sounds, and objects
care.care_socialization_tip_6: Visit pet-friendly stores and outdoor cafes
care.care_socialization_tip_7: Arrange safe play dates with vaccinated dogs
care.care_socialization_warning_0: Don't force fearful dogs into situations
care.care_socialization_warning_1: Ensure puppies are vaccinated before public areas
care.care_socialization_warning_2: One bad experience can create lasting fear
care.care_socialization_warning_3: Adult rescue dogs need slower, careful socialization
care.care_basic-training_description: Basic commands provide safety, enhance communication, and strengthen your bond.
care.care_basic-training_tip_1: Keep training sessions short and fun
care.care_basic-training_tip_2: Start with basics: sit, stay, come, down, leave it
care.care_basic-training_tip_3: Be consistent with commands and rules
care.care_basic-training_tip_4: Train in various locations for generalization
care.care_basic-training_tip_5: End sessions on a positive note
care.care_basic-training_tip_6: Practice recall in safe, enclosed areas first
care.care_basic-training_tip_7: Use high-value treats for challenging behaviors
care.care_basic-training_tip_8: Train before meals when dogs are motivated
care.care_nutrition-basics_description: Quality nutrition is the foundation of your dog's health and longevity.
care.care_nutrition-basics_tip_2: Provide fresh water at all times
care.care_nutrition-basics_tip_3: Avoid toxic foods (chocolate, grapes, onions, etc.)
care.care_nutrition-basics_tip_4: Consider your dog's activity level and health status
care.care_nutrition-basics_tip_7: Use treat calories as part of daily intake
care.care_nutrition-basics_warning_0: Obesity is the #1 preventable health issue
care.care_nutrition-basics_warning_1: Free feeding can lead to overeating
care.care_nutrition-basics_warning_2: Some human foods are toxic to dogs
care.care_home-safety_description: Creating a safe home environment prevents accidents and injuries.
care.care_home-safety_tip_4: Use baby gates for restricted areas
care.care_home-safety_tip_5: Store small objects that could be swallowed
care.care_home-safety_tip_6: Provide a safe, quiet space for your dog
care.care_home-safety_tip_7: Check yard for escape routes and hazards
care.care_home-safety_warning_0: Many common plants are toxic (lilies, azaleas, sago palms)
care.care_home-safety_warning_1: Antifreeze is extremely toxic and tastes sweet
care.care_home-safety_warning_2: Xylitol (artificial sweetener) is deadly to dogs
care.care_home-safety_warning_3: Small toys can be choking hazards
care.care_weather-safety_description: Protect your dog from extreme weather conditions.
care.care_weather-safety_tip_0: Never leave dogs in hot cars (even with windows cracked)
care.care_weather-safety_tip_1: Provide shade and water in summer
care.care_weather-safety_tip_3: Use pet-safe ice melt in winter
care.care_weather-safety_tip_5: Provide sweaters for small or short-haired dogs in cold
care.care_weather-safety_tip_6: Limit time outside in extreme temperatures
care.care_weather-safety_warning_0: Heatstroke can be fatal within minutes
care.care_weather-safety_warning_1: Paw pads can burn on hot pavement
care.care_weather-safety_warning_2: Salt and chemical ice melts can be toxic
care.care_weather-safety_warning_3: Hypothermia is dangerous for small/thin dogs
care.care_health-monitoring_description: Early detection of health issues leads to better outcomes.
care.care_health-monitoring_frequency: Daily observations, annual vet visits minimum
care.care_health-monitoring_tip_1: Check stools for consistency and abnormalities
care.care_health-monitoring_tip_2: Watch energy levels and behavior changes
care.care_health-monitoring_tip_3: Examine skin, coat, eyes, and ears weekly
care.care_health-monitoring_tip_5: Keep up with vaccinations and preventatives
care.care_health-monitoring_tip_6: Schedule annual wellness exams (bi-annual for seniors)
care.care_health-monitoring_tip_7: Know your dog's normal vital signs
care.care_health-monitoring_warning_0: Sudden behavior changes can indicate illness
care.care_health-monitoring_warning_1: Don't skip heartworm and flea prevention
care.care_health-monitoring_warning_2: Senior dogs need more frequent checkups
care.care_health-monitoring_warning_3: Some symptoms require immediate vet attention
care.care_parasite-prevention_description: Protecting your dog from parasites is crucial for their health and yours.
care.care_parasite-prevention_tip_0: Use vet-recommended flea, tick, and heartworm prevention
care.care_parasite-prevention_tip_2: Check for ticks after outdoor activities
care.care_parasite-prevention_tip_4: Wash bedding regularly in hot water
care.care_parasite-prevention_tip_5: Vacuum frequently if fleas are present
care.care_parasite-prevention_tip_6: Deworm puppies as recommended by vet
care.care_parasite-prevention_warning_0: Heartworm treatment is expensive and risky
care.care_parasite-prevention_warning_2: Fleas can cause anemia in small dogs
care.care_parasite-prevention_warning_3: Intestinal parasites can transfer to humans

nutrition.title: Dog Nutrition Guide
nutrition.subtitle: Complete feeding guidelines, nutritional needs, safe and toxic foods for your dog
nutrition.feedingScheduleSeniorValue: 2 meals per day (smaller, more frequent can help digestion)
nutrition.portionGuideNote: Exact portions depend on food calorie density, dog metabolism, and activity level. Always follow food packaging guidelines and adjust based on body condition.
nutrition.portionGuideTip1: Ribs should be easily felt but not visible
nutrition.portionGuideTip2: Visible waist when viewed from above
nutrition.portionGuideTip3: Tucked abdomen when viewed from side
nutrition.portionGuideTip4: Adjust portions if gaining or losing weight
nutrition.nutrition_toxic-foods_title: Foods That Are Toxic to Dogs
nutrition.nutrition_toxic-foods_content: These foods should NEVER be given to dogs as they can cause serious illness or death:
nutrition.nutrition_safe-human-foods_title: Human Foods Safe for Dogs (In Moderation)
nutrition.nutrition_safe-human-foods_content: These foods can be given as occasional treats, not exceeding 10% of daily calories:
nutrition.nutrition_feeding-guidelines-puppies_con: Puppies have different nutritional needs than adult dogs due to rapid growth and development.
nutrition.nutrition_feeding-guidelines-adults_cont: Adult dogs require balanced nutrition to maintain health and ideal weight.
nutrition.nutrition_feeding-guidelines-seniors_con: Senior dogs (7+ years for large breeds, 10+ for small breeds) have changing nutritional needs.
nutrition.nutrition_protein-needs_content: Protein is essential for muscle maintenance, immune function, and overall health.
nutrition.nutrition_carbohydrate-role_content: While not essential, carbohydrates provide energy and fiber for digestive health.
nutrition.nutrition_fat-needs_content: Fats provide concentrated energy, support cell function, and aid vitamin absorption.
nutrition.nutrition_vitamins-minerals_content: Complete dog foods contain necessary vitamins and minerals, but understanding their roles is helpful.
nutrition.nutrition_weight-management_content: Obesity affects over 50% of dogs and causes numerous health problems.
nutrition.nutrition_food-allergies_content: True food allergies are rare, but sensitivities can cause digestive or skin issues.
nutrition.nutrition_homemade-diets_content: Homemade diets can be healthy if properly formulated, but require careful planning.
nutrition.nutrition_raw-diets_content: Raw diets are controversial. Understand risks and benefits before choosing.
nutrition.nutrition_hydration_content: Water is the most important nutrient. Dehydration can quickly become life-threatening.
nutrition.nutrition_toxic-foods_item_0: Chocolate - Contains theobromine, toxic to dogs. Dark chocolate is most dangerous.
nutrition.nutrition_toxic-foods_item_1: Grapes and Raisins - Can cause kidney failure even in small amounts.
nutrition.nutrition_toxic-foods_item_2: Onions and Garlic - Damage red blood cells, causing anemia.
nutrition.nutrition_toxic-foods_item_3: Xylitol - Artificial sweetener in gum, candy, peanut butter. Causes liver failure.
nutrition.nutrition_toxic-foods_item_4: Macadamia Nuts - Cause weakness, vomiting, tremors, and hyperthermia.
nutrition.nutrition_toxic-foods_item_5: Avocado - Contains persin, toxic to dogs.
nutrition.nutrition_toxic-foods_item_6: Alcohol - Extremely dangerous, causes vomiting, diarrhea, breathing problems.
nutrition.nutrition_toxic-foods_item_7: Caffeine - Similar effects to chocolate toxicity.
nutrition.nutrition_toxic-foods_item_8: Cooked Bones - Can splinter and cause blockages or perforations.
nutrition.nutrition_toxic-foods_item_9: Raw Yeast Dough - Expands in stomach, produces alcohol.
nutrition.nutrition_toxic-foods_item_10: Salt - Large amounts cause sodium poisoning.
nutrition.nutrition_toxic-foods_item_11: Nutmeg - Contains myristicin, causes seizures and nervous system problems.
nutrition.nutrition_toxic-foods_item_12: Cherry Pits, Peach Pits, Apple Seeds - Contain cyanide.
nutrition.nutrition_safe-human-foods_item_0: Carrots - Low calorie, good for teeth. Raw or cooked.
nutrition.nutrition_safe-human-foods_item_1: Apples - Remove seeds and core. High in fiber and vitamins.
nutrition.nutrition_safe-human-foods_item_3: Watermelon - Seedless, remove rind. Hydrating treat.
nutrition.nutrition_safe-human-foods_item_4: Plain Cooked Chicken - No bones, skin, or seasoning.
nutrition.nutrition_safe-human-foods_item_5: Plain Cooked Fish - Salmon, tuna (boneless). Rich in omega-3s.
nutrition.nutrition_safe-human-foods_item_6: Plain Cooked Eggs - Excellent protein source.
nutrition.nutrition_safe-human-foods_item_7: Plain Pumpkin - Not pie filling. Great for digestion.
nutrition.nutrition_safe-human-foods_item_8: Sweet Potatoes - Cooked, plain. High in fiber.
nutrition.nutrition_safe-human-foods_item_9: Green Beans - Plain, fresh, frozen, or canned (no salt).
nutrition.nutrition_safe-human-foods_item_10: Peanut Butter - Xylitol-free only! High calorie.
nutrition.nutrition_safe-human-foods_item_11: Plain Yogurt - Small amounts. Good probiotics.
nutrition.nutrition_safe-human-foods_item_12: Cooked White Rice - Bland, good for upset stomachs.
nutrition.nutrition_safe-human-foods_item_14: Strawberries - In moderation. High in sugar.
nutrition.nutrition_feeding-guidelines-puppies_ite: Feed puppy-specific food formulated for growth
Transition to adult food between 12-18 months (varies by breed)
Large breeds need puppy food longer for proper bone development
Measure portions according to food packaging and vet recommendations
Monitor body condition - ribs should be easily felt but not visible
Avoid overfeeding - excess weight can harm developing joints
nutrition.nutrition_feeding-guidelines-adults_item: Measure portions based on weight, activity level, and metabolism
Feed at consistent times each day
Provide fresh water at all times
Adjust portions if dog gains or loses weight
Active dogs need more calories than sedentary dogs
Working dogs may need performance formulas
Pregnant or nursing dogs have increased caloric needs
Treats should not exceed 10% of daily calories
Don't free feed (leaving food out all day) - leads to obesity
nutrition.nutrition_feeding-guidelines-seniors_ite: Switch to senior-formula food with appropriate calories
Senior dogs are less active - reduce calories to prevent obesity
Higher protein helps maintain muscle mass
Easier-to-digest proteins benefit aging digestive systems
Soften food if dental issues present
Monitor weight closely - sudden changes may indicate illness
Consult vet about supplements for specific health issues
nutrition.nutrition_protein-needs_item_0: AAFCO minimum for adult dogs: 18% protein
nutrition.nutrition_protein-needs_item_2: Active and working dogs benefit from higher protein (25-30%)
nutrition.nutrition_protein-needs_item_4: Animal-based proteins are more complete than plant-based
nutrition.nutrition_protein-needs_item_5: Common sources: chicken, beef, lamb, fish, eggs
nutrition.nutrition_protein-needs_item_6: Protein needs increase for pregnant/nursing dogs
nutrition.nutrition_protein-needs_item_7: Senior dogs may need higher protein to maintain muscle
nutrition.nutrition_protein-needs_item_8: Dogs with certain kidney conditions may need restricted protein
nutrition.nutrition_protein-needs_item_9: Consult your vet for individual protein needs
nutrition.nutrition_carbohydrate-role_item_0: Dogs can digest carbohydrates when properly cooked
nutrition.nutrition_carbohydrate-role_item_1: Provide quick energy for active dogs
nutrition.nutrition_carbohydrate-role_item_2: Fiber aids digestion and helps with weight management
nutrition.nutrition_carbohydrate-role_item_3: Good sources: sweet potato, rice, oats, barley
nutrition.nutrition_carbohydrate-role_item_5: Some grain-free diets linked to heart issues (DCM)
nutrition.nutrition_carbohydrate-role_item_6: Dogs can have grain allergies, but it's uncommon
nutrition.nutrition_carbohydrate-role_item_7: Whole grains are more nutritious than refined
nutrition.nutrition_carbohydrate-role_item_8: Balance carbs with protein and fats
nutrition.nutrition_carbohydrate-role_item_9: Individual dogs tolerate different carb sources
nutrition.nutrition_fat-needs_item_0: AAFCO minimum for adult dogs: 5% fat
nutrition.nutrition_fat-needs_item_2: Most quality dog foods contain 12-20% fat
nutrition.nutrition_fat-needs_item_3: Essential fatty acids (omega-3 and omega-6) required
nutrition.nutrition_fat-needs_item_5: Aids absorption of vitamins A, D, E, K
nutrition.nutrition_fat-needs_item_6: Provides twice the calories of protein or carbs
nutrition.nutrition_fat-needs_item_7: Fish oil rich in omega-3s supports joints and cognition
nutrition.nutrition_fat-needs_item_8: Low-fat diets needed for pancreatitis-prone dogs
nutrition.nutrition_fat-needs_item_9: Too much fat can lead to obesity and pancreatitis
nutrition.nutrition_vitamins-minerals_item_0: Calcium and Phosphorus - Bone and teeth health, proper ratio crucial
nutrition.nutrition_vitamins-minerals_item_1: Vitamin A - Vision, immune function, skin health
nutrition.nutrition_vitamins-minerals_item_2: Vitamin D - Calcium absorption, bone health
nutrition.nutrition_vitamins-minerals_item_4: B Vitamins - Energy metabolism, nervous system
nutrition.nutrition_vitamins-minerals_item_9: Don't supplement without vet approval - can be harmful
nutrition.nutrition_weight-management_item_0: Consult vet to determine ideal weight
nutrition.nutrition_weight-management_item_1: Switch to weight management formula (lower calories)
nutrition.nutrition_weight-management_item_2: Measure all food - no free feeding
nutrition.nutrition_weight-management_item_3: Reduce treats or use low-calorie options (carrots, green beans)
nutrition.nutrition_weight-management_item_5: Feed smaller, more frequent meals to prevent hunger
nutrition.nutrition_weight-management_item_7: Weight loss should be gradual: 1-2% body weight per week
nutrition.nutrition_weight-management_item_9: Entire family must follow the diet plan
nutrition.nutrition_food-allergies_item_0: Common allergens: beef, dairy, wheat, chicken, eggs, soy
nutrition.nutrition_food-allergies_item_1: Symptoms: itching, skin inflammation, ear infections, digestive upset
nutrition.nutrition_food-allergies_item_2: Diagnosis requires elimination diet trial (8-12 weeks)
nutrition.nutrition_food-allergies_item_3: Novel protein diets use proteins dog hasn't eaten before
nutrition.nutrition_food-allergies_item_4: Hydrolyzed protein diets break down proteins to reduce reactions
nutrition.nutrition_food-allergies_item_5: Limited ingredient diets simplify identifying triggers
nutrition.nutrition_food-allergies_item_6: Don't confuse with food intolerance (less severe)
nutrition.nutrition_food-allergies_item_7: Work with vet for proper diagnosis
nutrition.nutrition_food-allergies_item_9: Stick to one protein source during trial
nutrition.nutrition_homemade-diets_item_0: Consult with veterinary nutritionist for balanced recipes
nutrition.nutrition_homemade-diets_item_1: Must include proper ratios of protein, fats, carbs, vitamins, minerals
nutrition.nutrition_homemade-diets_item_2: Supplements often needed to meet nutritional requirements
nutrition.nutrition_homemade-diets_item_3: More time-consuming and expensive than commercial food
nutrition.nutrition_homemade-diets_item_4: Ingredients must be consistent and measured
nutrition.nutrition_homemade-diets_item_5: Cooked diets safer than raw for most dogs
nutrition.nutrition_homemade-diets_item_6: Not recommended for dogs with medical conditions without vet guidance
nutrition.nutrition_homemade-diets_item_7: Regular blood work to monitor nutritional status
nutrition.nutrition_homemade-diets_item_8: Recipes online are often incomplete or unbalanced
nutrition.nutrition_homemade-diets_item_9: Can be good option for dogs with multiple allergies
nutrition.nutrition_raw-diets_item_0: BARF = Biologically Appropriate Raw Food or Bones and Raw Food
nutrition.nutrition_raw-diets_item_1: Proponents cite shinier coats, cleaner teeth, better digestion
nutrition.nutrition_raw-diets_item_2: Risks include bacterial contamination (Salmonella, E. coli)
nutrition.nutrition_raw-diets_item_3: Risk to immunocompromised people and dogs
nutrition.nutrition_raw-diets_item_4: Risk of nutritional imbalances if not properly formulated
nutrition.nutrition_raw-diets_item_5: Bones can cause choking, broken teeth, intestinal blockage
nutrition.nutrition_raw-diets_item_9: If choosing raw, work with veterinary nutritionist
nutrition.nutrition_raw-diets_item_10: Commercial raw diets may be safer than homemade
nutrition.nutrition_raw-diets_item_11: Not recommended for puppies or immune-compromised dogs
nutrition.nutrition_hydration_item_0: Dogs need approximately 1 ounce of water per pound of body weight daily
nutrition.nutrition_hydration_item_1: More needed in hot weather, after exercise, or with certain health conditions
nutrition.nutrition_hydration_item_2: Fresh, clean water should always be available
nutrition.nutrition_hydration_item_3: Change water at least once daily
nutrition.nutrition_hydration_item_4: Wash bowls regularly to prevent bacteria
nutrition.nutrition_hydration_item_5: Multiple water stations for multi-dog homes
nutrition.nutrition_hydration_item_6: Wet food provides some hydration, dry food provides none
nutrition.nutrition_hydration_item_7: Signs of dehydration: dry gums, loss of skin elasticity, lethargy
nutrition.nutrition_hydration_item_8: Excessive drinking can indicate diabetes or kidney disease
nutrition.nutrition_hydration_item_9: Monitor water intake - sudden changes warrant vet visit
nutrition.nutrition_hydration_item_10: Bring water on walks and trips
nutrition.nutrition_hydration_item_11: Ice cubes can be refreshing treats

health.emergencyNote: Keep your emergency vet's phone number and the nearest 24-hour animal hospital address readily available at all times.

serviceDogs.title: Service Dogs Guide
serviceDogs.subtitle: Comprehensive guide to service dogs, their roles, training, and legal rights
serviceDogs.intro1: Service dogs are specially trained dogs that perform specific tasks to assist people with disabilities. Unlike emotional support animals or therapy dogs, service dogs are protected under federal law and have public access rights.
serviceDogs.intro2: These remarkable animals undergo extensive training (typically 18-24 months) to master skills that directly mitigate their handler's disability. Service dogs provide life-changing independence and assistance to their partners.
serviceDogs.trainingCostsIntro: Training a service dog typically costs $20,000-$50,000 when including:
serviceDogs.trainingCostsNote: Many organizations provide service dogs at no cost to qualified individuals through fundraising and donations.
serviceDogs.legalNote: Businesses cannot require documentation or certification as a condition of entry. They can only ask if the animal is required for a disability and what task it performs.

gallery.wantYourDog: Want to see your dog here?
gallery.wantYourDogDesc: Book our services and we'll send you beautiful photos of your furry friend!

tools.calorieNote4: Monitor body condition and adjust as needed
tools.calorieNote5: Consult your vet for specific dietary needs
